title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Top quality audio after a few adjustments
author: P. Dobrinen
content: This review is about the audio features of the JBL Vibe Beam earbuds.I'm an audio engineer so audio quality is very important to me. As such, I use wired connections as much as possible to maintain the integrity of the audio signal. However, many newer consumer-level products no longer have audio jacks, so I finally decided to invest in some wireless earbuds as a backup to the other earphones and headphones that I use. I didn't want to spend a lot of money as I didn't foresee myself using this product very much, and since this is my first foray into wireless audio earphones, if they were just ok or they broke after a while, then I wouldn't feel too bad about the little money that I spent. Also, I wanted to focus on finding wireless earbuds with excellent audio quality first as I already have an excellent high-end bluetooth earpiece for cell phone use, and I wouldn't be using this product as a bluetooth headset for my phone.After doing much research, I chose the JBL Vibe Beam's as they were at my price point, I'm familiar with JBL products, and I could reasonably expect that they were likely deliver the high audio quality that I've come to expect from JBL products. In my research, I read reviews that complained about the harshness of the high end with high frequency instruments like cymbals or the lack of bass, so I was a bit concerned.When I received and started listening to my JBL Vibe Beams I understood what people were talking about. However, to correct the issues, first, one must have a great fit of the earbuds in their ears. I'm fortunate, in that with the medium tips that were already installed on the Vibe Beams, they made a snug fit in my ears right out of the box. If you find that these earbuds do not fit well in your ears it might be worthwhile to invest in a separate set of variable sized earbud tips, or try tips from one of your other well-fitting earbuds, if you have them. Once the earbuds were seated properly in my ear, that took care of the poor bass issue. (I have not worn them long-term so I can't speak to them falling out of my ear, as others have mentioned, but they seem to stay in pretty well.)For the misaligned frequency response issue, fortunately, the JBL Headphone app that you can install on your cell phone includes a ten-band graphic equalizer that you can use to make adjustments to the frequency response of your earbuds. After listening to several of the reference tracks I use to check new audio equipment or my mixes against, I found that the only adjustments needed were carving out some of the upper midrange and making a very slight boost in the bottom end of the lower frequency spectrum. I've included a screenshot of my EQ curve which I based on the Bass preset in the JBL app. You can't tell as there is no dB scale on the side, but I needed to cut or boost by only 1-2 dB. I find that my new EQ curve gives a more balanced frequency response than what came out of the box, and matches up well against the reference speaker system and headphones that I use for my audio mixing and mastering work. I invite you to use my EQ curve as a starting point and adjust as sounds best to you.I also read reviews complaining about the apparent lack of volume of the Vibe Beams. I connected the JBL's to several different sources (phone, computer, TV, MP3 player, etc.) and I found that the overall maximum volume (with limiter off) is relatively lower than wired speaker versions. However, the input to the JBL's is relative to the maximum output of the source itself. I found that the loudest level I could get came from my iPhone and the lowest level output came from my MP3 player (which probably doesn't offer much output anyway being a tiny portable unit). As a comparison, I did a side-by-side test of the JBL's with my wife's AirPods (2nd gen). What I found was that the JBL's offered an almost identical audio output level as the AirPods with any of the sources I used so that confirmed that the output level of the JBL's has more to do with the source (and the source material as some songs are mastered at a lower volume than other songs) than with the earbuds themselves. During my test, I put the JBL's at their maximum volume output (one tap at a time on the left bud to raise the volume). Also, I noticed during my testing that the AirPods had a pleasing midrange sound perfect for listening to podcasts or watching video, but the JBL's excelled at full-range sound on the bottom and top ends of the frequency spectrum which made them sound much better over all and well-suited for music or listening to explosive action scenes in movies.And speaking of movies, the JBL app has a switchable audio/video mode. The video mode reduces the latency of the delivery of audio against picture, so there isn't a noticeable lip-sync issue with dialogue in a scene. However, there is a slight degradation in the audio quality of 'video' mode versus 'audio' mode, but you will have to make the determination if the change in audio quality is acceptable to you.As a side note, I included a picture of the inner side of the earbuds. The 'L' and 'R' designations on the earbuds are tiny as you can see, plus they are the same color as the earbuds themselves, so they are very hard to see. I wish JBL had made the L/R letters bigger or at least made them a different color so they would be easier to see.The pairing process was fairly easy with all my bluetooth-capable devices and the range was good, only dropping out after walking approximately 60-70 feet from the source. There was one momentary dropout during my listening but that could be due to my wife using her AirPods the same time as I was using the JBL's.I can't speak to the other features of the JBL Vibe Beams as I don't intend to use them, but as far as audio quality goes, with just a few minor tweaks, these bluetooth earbuds can go from sounding like a $50 pair of earbuds to a $500 pair of reference earphones.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Decent ear buds, but fit isn't exact and battery life is questionable

I've had it fall out once already when just bending over to pick something up off the floor.They are also difficult to get out of the case, the lid should open further or just have a way to grab a hold of them easier.The battery life is ok, but doesn't seem to be anywhere near the 32 hours listed, including the recharge feature of the case. I've gotten about half that, before they kept telling me they were "low battery". And I had to charge them and the case both back up.all in all, these may work good for some people. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars excellent battery life. lots of good feature ideas that don't really work IRL.

content: When i purchased these I didn't know about the touch controls features. so if you touch one of them it will pause what you are listening to or if you touch the other it can adjust the volume depending on where you tap it. it's very sensitive and I find anything that touches it, hair or hat will pause your podcast. You can turn this feature off with the app. The "find my buds" feature in the app for this is great in theory, but pretty useless in real life practice. (I lost one of them a week after owning them.) unless they are currently on and bluetooth connected to the phone with the app you can't make it ping the bud and make a sound to find it. so despite knowing where I lost the bud and knowing i was in range I couldn't find it. So i now have one earbud.The sound quality is good but the noise cancelling isn't capable of cancelling out a mower or a weed wacker enough for you to hear what you were listening to clearly. the pass through sound feature isn't really useful either, on this scale the mic quality just isn't good enough to do that and not have people sound like old robots. It does work.. it just makes everything sound like an old mono radio broadcast.The battery life is really the best feature of these buds. I can listen for 5 hours straight and not have to put it back on the charger. I only listen to podcasts on my single remaining ear bud, maybe if you listened to something with more bass it would drain faster. but for my purposes it's perfect. I also really like that the app shows you the remaining battery percentage of each bud

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Really good sound, but...
author: Customer
content: For a $50 pair of ear buds, these sound impressive. I've paid twice the price before and not been nearly this impressed. They bring a new clarity of sound to some albums in which I gave been previously disappointed, eg Clockwork Angels, which has always sounded muddy, even on my custom home sound system. My music tastes have a wide range; whether classical, big band jazz, prog rock, shoe gazer, etc, these buds really deliver for the price. With the app, there is good ability to adjust the sound and other settings, which is very nice, if not unique to JBL.However, there is one big caveat. With all the ear buds I have used over the years, I have never, EVER had such a pain-in-the-*$$ time getting these damn things out of their charging case!! They are stupidly hard to grasp-- they sit deep in the case, don't have a good way to grab them, and the lid very much is in the way of trying to get to them. If you buy these, know you have to be very careful and deliberate about removing them from the case or you will definitely drop them and ultimately ruin them. And if you have big fingers, seriously consider another product...unless you just get a kick out of being extremely frustrated.JBL, if you're listening (sorry for the pun), redesign the case so the ear buds rest in them 180 degrees from the way they do now, increase the surface area to pull them out, and please, PLEASE, redesign the case to have the lid flip farther back out of the way so that people with even average- sized fingers can get to these ear buds!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Quality Earbuds with some Caveats
author: Noah & Brooke
content: These are great earbuds, especially when discounted. I feel it necessary to say I purchased these at 50% off, and for that price they are definitely worth it. At $100, I would definitely go for Samsung's or something similar.Here is the rundown.Pros:- Long battery life- Good noise cancelling, about 50-60%% effective or so (not as good as headphones obviously, but good)- Sleek design- Can adjust to stay in your ear pretty well- JBL app is available for Android at least, and allows you to easily manage and fine tune your audio experience which is greatCons:- get very uncomfortable after wearing for a while (could be the particular fit piece I use or way I'm wearing them, not sure, but it hurts after awhile)- noise cancelling, while good, is not amazing, and it causes noises outside to be kinda sharp and close-feeling (like someone yanking on your earbud cord back when earbuds were wired)Overall, great choice at $50. Like I said before though, I wouldn't recommend at full price because of the comfort and noise cancellation oddities. I have to go back to my Wyze wireless headphones after a while to give my ears a break.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Low-end Offerings
author: NORMAN GARCIA
content: Purchased these JBL Tune Buds a few weeks ago as I had misplaced my Javbra 5 Buds and needed a quick and inexpensive replacement.Here are my observations:Fit - I am of average ear size (I think). I tried all three sizes of bud that came with the packaging. The medium size fit best but by best, I mean just adequate. The silicon buds were cheap feeling and lacked any stiffness that might have helped secure them better to my ear and helped/assisted the ANC when turned on.Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) - I live in a metropolitan area that is chronically loud. If you live in a quieter area, these might work for you. For me, the ANC is poor to adequate and I suspect the ill fitting bud plays into this factor.Software - I feel the software is mediocore at best. I use these buds for playing music and for remote meetings via MS TEAMs. Once the TEAMs meeting starts the software deactivates ANC and you are able to hear the "ambient' sounds from your surrounding environment. I can hear the meeting participants fine but they complain that they have trouble hearing me. They tell me that the barely hear my voice and instead hear the noise around me. Not sure of the logic making this "auto ANC off" for meetings a thing with the buds/software. Ultimately, I just listen and don't offer much feedback because it ends up being a distraction.Talk - On individual calls, friends and family hear me fine.Meetings - not recommended for meetings as the software is set to turn off ANC once a meeting begins.Gaming - I feel that young people could use these phones to game if they are in a quiet setting like their room.Price - I feel that these JBL Tune Buds were priced adequately around $50.Final Thoughts - If you are willing to pay $25 more I recommend Jabra 5 buds. Your ears will thank you for it.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Mastering Engineer Approved
author: Jenn
content: A lot of pros with one con.I didn‚Äôt think I had a lot of time for earbuds during the day, so I started off trying a cheap pair. They were $20 or something with 4.8 stars and reviews like, ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt used my Airpods since buying these!‚Äù so I thought that sounded perfect.They sucked. The sound was harsh, they became painful after extended use, noise cancelling was barely noticeable, etc. I can‚Äôt actually remember all of the problems at this point. BUT they sold me on the functionality of wireless headphones.Fast-forward to a few months later - it‚Äôs Black Friday and I bite on these because they‚Äôre on sale. I was a little hesitant because they had a lowly 4.2 stars. Turns out average reviews aren‚Äôt everything.These are the polar opposite of the highly-reviewed, cheap headphones I tried: they‚Äôre comfortable, and the sound is amazing. As the title implies, I master audio so this is not a hollow endorsement. The cheap ones had hyped bass, missing mids, and painful presence/treble. These are very flat and well-performing by comparison, and can be EQ‚Äôd. The noise cancelling is also VERY respectable. I frequently work around loud sources and am sensitive to loud noises, and I have accidentally left these in when I intended to swap for earplugs, because the performance is similar.I love the app. Being able to select between audio quality vs. video sync‚Äôing is awesome when I want to watch live musical performances where sync issues play with your mind. Being able to create custom EQ settings is very important to me too.The con is that you have to take them out of the case to power them on. It‚Äôs not a huge deal - it‚Äôs easy to pop them in for a split second if they‚Äôve timed out or something. But there has been one occasion that I ran somewhere and forgot the case. I intend to live my life without dependence on crap like headphones, so no big deal - take a break.I would normally give something like this 4 stars because that power-on function is a notable miscalculation on JBL‚Äôs part, but it deserves a much better average review than it has so I‚Äôm doing my part to raise it. In everyday life it‚Äôs not that big of a deal unless you‚Äôre the kind of person who loves to find things to complain about.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good earbuds, not fantastic
author: Frank
content: I use many different earbuds and headphones. These JBL Tune buds produce a good sound with my iPhone, especially when using the JBL app which has preset equalizer settings for different sounds and can deliver amazing base. Overall these are fairly good earbuds at a sale price of around $50. The box includes 3 pairs of silicon tips, small, medium and large, the silicon material is too smooth and too thin, they slide out easily and do not sit very securely for me, but this is very subjective and can be different for everyone. The noise canceling is only ok, in my opinion it provides about 40-50% background noise cancelation (personal opinion, not scientifically measured). The sound quality is very good but it seems the volume level seems low compared to other buds I have. The microphone seems to function well, I have not heard complaints from people I have called so I assume it is good. Overall, pretty decent buds but not fantastic, I was expecting more as a JBL brand
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic sound, great battery life, a great buy!
author: TheRevenite
content: I bought these on the Black Friday sale and man, I'm so glad I did. I have several pairs of the lesser Vibes, which sound good, but these blow them out of the water.First, let's address the fitment. I see many say they don't fit, they fall out, or feel like they're going to fall out. Don't put the large ear pads on if you don't have large ear canal openings! This will cause the earbuds to push themselves out. Too large will push them out, while too small will obviously not have enough to grip your ear. Test them all to find the right fit, if not, reach out to JBL, I'm sure they have replacement pads of other sizes. You can also buy them here on Amazon as they're pretty universal.I find pushing them in, and turning them into place, with the proper pads, netted a great seal and no falling out.You HAVE to install the app on your phone; otherwise, you're getting the flat sound your phone manufacturer decided sounded good. The JBL app is available for Apple and Android - and it makes a massive difference, especially with the noise cancellation and frequency response.With these, I'm hearing songs I've listened to for decades for the first time. I'm hearing effects and instruments I never heard in the music. These are that clear. They also don't kill my ears! I've tried earbuds from $5 to $300, and while the more expensive ones sounded terrific, they hurt my ears physically. With these, I get great sound and a great fit with a tremendous battery life.I'm reading a lot of negative reviews where either the fit or the sound is the problem. Most of these would be positive if people were provided with either longer pads so they go a bit further into the ear and more sizes and those with sound complaints would actually install the app. Mine sounded horrible with the Dolby equalizer baked into Android 13. Installing the app AND turning off any phone equalizer or sound enhancer was the solution. I'd definitely buy these again!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Finally found decent performing earbuds
author: Photographer
content: My standard for headphones is fairly high. I have a few pairs of high-end (also expensive) wired headphones for indoor, critical listening. I also have a pair of inexpensive earbuds for exercise. The sound quality is obviously subpar. I have been looking for a replacement.I bought and returned many over the last couple years; none lived up to my standard. Most of them had poor sound quality. I did buy one pair last year that was decent, but it had connection problems. So I returned it.I pretty much gave up until I came across this one. The price was too good to pass up. It was delivered not quickly, but within the promised time frame. Given my experience, I have low expectations. But the JBL brand name does give me some hope of acceptable quality.BT Connection was fast and secure with no problems so far. Sound quality is much better than I expected, especially for the price. While the sound stage is not as open as my high-end wired headphones, imagining is excellent, which I did not expect. Tonal balance is also excellent with no treble fatigue or excessive bass; I set the equalizer to neutral flat. I can wear it for prolong periods. I like it enough to wear it while moving around the house.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 19, 2024

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Wanted to really like these
author: Jason
content: Pros:Reputation Brand NameGood sound with JBL Headphone appPlenty of bass with JBL Headphone appCONS:FitBluetooth disconnectsI purchased these after mt galaxy bud 2 died, due to one bud falling out into my pool last year then finally died about a month ago.My primary use for ear buds is listening to music while doing yard work (mowing, weed eating, edging) and during pool maintenance (brushing the walls and vacuuming).When I first received these, I downloaded the app and they paired nicely with no issues. Capsule charge was at 75% while both buds were at 100%.Next I tried placing them in my ears. When i placed them in my ears and turn them counterclockwise the weren't very comfortable and felt loose like they were going to fall out, however they did say in place when i tilted my head to either side and shook my head. These earbuds are supplied additional ear cushions. I tried the bigger ones and for my ears these were too big for my ear canal and would not stay in very well. I tried the smaller ones and these wouldn't hold in place. I'd like to say they were like Goldilocks and the 3 bears, but none were just right. The closest for me were the medium size, but I still didn't trust them staying in while doing yard work.Today was the first day I've had to really put them to the test. I place them in and fiddle with them for a bit to get a "snug" fit. The only way I could achieve this was by turning them so that the J in the JBL logo was at about a 180 degrees facing upwards.I started Spotify and proceeded to start the yard work. I noticed myself constantly fiddling with the earbud, because the kept feeling like the were going to fall out, enough so that I kept activating the voice pass through.After about a hour and a half into the yard work I was met with a bluetooth disconnected message. When I looked at my phone (Samsung galaxy s23 ultra) it showed bluetooth was enabled and the buds were paired. I started Spotify again and the music resumed. So I was like ok????I did about another 2 hrs of yard work and they stayed connected, but I still constantly felt they were going to fall out.With today's experience, I will not be using these near my poolWould I recommend these to a friend? Probably notDo i think these were worth what I paid for them? No, with the fit issue, these should cost closer to $19.99

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Clarity and Dynamics, lack fullness
author: J
content: I usually buy earbuds with a more balanced sound profile (Bose QuietComfort, Samsung Buds+, Jabra Elite 7 Pro). The same goes with Sony C500:1) The base is precise and it is not bloomy or overwhelming2) The treble is a little bright, but not harsh (Jabra Elite 7 Pro has a treble that hurts my ears). I use the equalizer to dial down the treble and dial up the mid just a bit to make it sounds slightly warmer.3) The mid is very detail. I can hear the singers express their emotions very clearly. Much more detail than Bose to my ears (but Bose sounds fuller and richer).4) The sound is dynamic. I feel it can bring out the excitement in music without being overwhelming (more than Bose but Bose has better instrument separation and "layering")Other Pros:1) It is super comfortable. I can listen to it many hours without taking it off.2) The equalizer is much better than Jabra. It shows the frequency as well as the decibel.A few things to watch out for:1) Even though the sound is very detail but it also sounds thin, especially for male vocals with deeper voice. Using the equalizer to dial up the mids helps a little bit.2) It sound pretty bad on voice calling.3) Noise Cancellation is not good. I can hear people chatting in the office. I guess it is a give-and-take. This earbud does not require a deep in-ear fit (to be comfortable), so it could be harder to get good noise cancellation. On the other hand, Jabra has good passive noise cancellation, but it is not nearly as comfortable (it has a deeper in-ear fit).I primarily look for a inexpensive earbuds to use in office with good sound and comfort. Given that I buy it on sale, I am happy with this investment. It has almost everything that I am looking for. Wish that it would sound a bit fuller (then it would be perfect).
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 16, 2022

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great all around wireless earbud for a great price
author: Mike N
content: I purchased these on daily deal from Amazon for $59 or so, and for the money I've been extremely pleased so far.Comfort: they fit well and are snug, they come with three sizes of tips so getting a good fit shouldn't be hard. They stay in place very well during intensive workoutsSound quality: For the money, I've pretty impressed with the sound quality. I own an amp and DAC, planar magnetic headphones, and a pair of wired balanced armature earbuds. So I love good headphones. These give my balanced armature earbuds a good run for their money. These don't have huge bass, but the bass is punchy and well controlled. Highs and mids are good, and there's decent separation and a nice airiness about these. Overall, these have a very well controlled sound profile and work well with most any music genre. These also isolate pretty well, so good that I see no need for wireless buds with noise cancellation, which I personally think is a gimmick that only causes increased drain on the batteries.Battery life: pretty decent, these don't have noise cancelling tech, so battery life is much better than buds that have that tech. One important note, I've found the right earbud will drain faster than the left if I use it frequently to advance or replay tracks.Sony headphone app: I'd recommend downloading the Sony headphone app as this allows you some equalizer features and let's you turn off the buds using the app. Also, the app has some other bells and whistles like an ear analyzer that takes a picture of your ear and optimizes sound to fit your ears. However, you'll need to download one of several 3rd party apps to take advantage of this feature.Overall, these are a fantastic deal for the money, with typical Sony quality and functionality. They work great with my Iphone and integrate with Siri, so you'll have that functionality as well.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great ear buds
author: Amazon Customer
content: I purchased these a couple weeks ago. I wanted to write an honest review after using them for a while.I'm very happy with them. I tried a different brand but returned them after a couple days. I wear them for a couple hours while exercising and a few hours after--I can wear them about 2 days like this until I need to recharge. I don't like to recharge until they are below 20%. The charging case will charge them up to about 75% in about an hour or less.I gave them a 4 because they are small and will sometimes slip out of my fingers when I remove them from my ears.I have the Bose noise cancelling over ear headphones and these are (almost) comparable to those for sound.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Very good
author: ariel villalona
content:
these in ears have several points to highlight.

1. Noise cancellation is passive, even with the headphones turned off, the outside noise is greatly reduced. Already with music on, it cancels out like 85% of the noise I feel this percentage lower depending on how loud the outside noise is.

2. The comfort is super super good, since I received them I use it 10 hours in a row every day, and it's as if I didn't have anything on. They don't fall off if I move my head, it doesn't bother, they fit well.

3. connectivity, the distance is very good. I can leave my cell phone in one place and walk around the house without losing sound quality.

4. I don't know if the battery is due to my use, but it lasts longer than the brand says. I charge them once every 3, 4 days.

5. the functions (buttons) are easy to use, and even though they are physical buttons, it doesn't bother to press them. And here's why I don't give them 5 stars:

when I use a single earphone, I lose all the functions of the headset that I'm not using. In my opinion, they should have kept the options of the right earphone, which are to change and pause the songs, because if I use only the left one I have to use the mobile phone if I want to pause or change a song.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not this time Sony!

content: I bought these ear buds mainly for gym workouts and jogging outside. And overall they are decent earbuds but if you're a music holic like me than you may not be too satisfied. I used them for about a week before the battery was even close to dying. And I don't use them just a few times a day, I listen to music bascally all day long after work and at gym. So I am extremely impressed with the battery life. Also, they feel very comfortable in your ear, you can barely feel they are in there. Another pro is that they are easy to store in their case and the case is small enough to put in your pocket to carry around. Cons: Doesn't have the best noise cancellation and volume is kind of low. I am able to hear a lot of noise even when volume is all the way up. My main thing about earbuds is not hearing the outside world. I like to be focused on me and the music Im listening to. title: 1.0 out of 5 stars Readme 1st: Not for Windows users... Mediocre sound quality even by Sony standards.
author: Persepolis
content: This is on the cheaper end of Sony's offerings, given the price tag I would at a minimum expect good quality... wrong. It falls short of a 10 year old wired Sony MDREX58V, at 3x the price...Here are the pro's and con's:Pro: Quick bluetooth connect/disconnects.Con: Audio quality is just BAD... tinny and weak out of the box. It falls short of an older Sony MDREX58V I have which is only $20, it falls short of most $20-$30 no-name ear buds, and falls, and falls pretty close to a set of freebie earbuds I got while flying United a few years back. This is not good! I think Sony tried to differentiate between their high end offerings so badly that they killed the quality on this one so they can fill the lower price tier.Pro: Comfortable fit, lighter than some of the other ear buds I've used.Con: Software to control behavior is only available on Android and iOS... so if you're using it on a Windows PC, while it will pair and it will "function", it sounds like crap... and it will stay that way. In 2019, there were about 850mil iPhones in use... and about 900mil Windows PC's in use... not sure the what ledge the MBA's hit their heads on before deciding Windows users don't get the app thats needed to properly use these earbuds. For yuks sake, I do have both an iOS device and an Android... and installed the app on both of those... and the sound quality didn't get much better by adjusting the equalization envelope. Increasing the base just seemed to eat away at the midrange... It was weird to say the least.Pro: It can be reasonably loud. So you're getting mediocre sound, just loud mediocre sound... LOL.Anyways... summary: This is a low price offering from Sony that has been neutered so they can offer you something for $60... the only problem is that it performs worse than the $20 offering from others.Lack of a Windows app was not a particularly good decision given how low performing these are... a little bit of signal processing could have helped save these a bit...Summary: Save your money... Go with something cheaper or better... these miss the mark.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very impressive!
author: David L
content: I have enjoyed just about everything about using these. The sound quality is pretty great, the battery life is exceptional, the range is good enough that I can take the garbage out without taking these out... There's very little to dislike. And there are one or two nitpicks I have. The first is that, while the headphones recharge incredibly quickly in the carrying case (it takes about an hour for them to go from 0-100%, in my experience), the case itself charges pretty slowly. I would recommend charging it overnight. The second is that there are still some small technical problems. The headphones occasionally don't charge for whatever reason (this is typically fixed by just slightly moving them in their charging compartments), and I occasionally do need to restart my laptop to get them to reconnect. Neither of those are dealbreakers, and I would highly recommend these headphones, especially if they're going to stay at $70 for the foreseeable future.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sony Quality Shines Through with these Earbuds!
author: Shawshank
content: I ordered these earbuds because I wanted a quality set of earbuds that weren't a cheap throwaway pair after a year but didn't want to drop the coin on a set of Apple or Bose earbuds. Sony has a good rep in the consumer electronics space and after doing a little research outside of Shamazon, I decided I would give the WF-C500's a shot. A few things I like about these specific buds.1. Fitment - they fit in my ears well and they stay in my ears without causing hot spots or pain points.2. Battery life - I can't give you a precise number, but I can use these earbuds throughout the day and even into the night and still have some battery life in the morning.3. Sound - These specific earbuds I use primarily for listening to Audible audiobooks, so I don't need an eardrum ticking base or eye-watering treble highs, that said I did test these out with a few of my favorite artists - Hank Williams, Willie Nelson, Armin Van Buuren, Tiesto, AC/DC, old Van Halen, Vivaldi, the usual stuff we all listen to and in each style of music, I was very pleased, it was accurately represented within the context of having a half thimble-sized device stuck in my ear. Win. I also use these for phone calls, when someone calls and interrupts my audiobook, and I've always gotten good feedback from the other person on the call, in terms of clarity, volume of voice, and even outdoors, the wind management seemed to not negatively impact my call.4. Earbud controls - There is a pro/con to the way you control these earbuds. I'll flat-out tell you I am not a fan of the touch-sensitive earbuds. I have big hand and rarely do I touch it in the way it wants to be touched and I end up hanging up on someone while I'm trying to turn up the volume or whatever the case is. The WF-C500's are more of a button-press kind of thing. It's tactile - you know exactly what your finger is doing when it's doing it because of that tactile feedback. I freaking love that. Super-duper simple!! So what's the con Shawshank? Glad you asked. It's probably a horrible habit but I use one of the earbuds when I go to sleep. Usually an audiobook, might be some Ludovico Einaudi, or that soothing ocean or thunderstorm sound with some good ol' scripture in the background. The problem is I'm a side-sleeper and SOMETIMES when I roll over to the side that has the earbud in it, the pillow will act like my finger and hit that little tactile button and pause whatever I'm listening to. I can hit it again and be a little more careful when I put my head back on the pillow, but that does happen. It's probably a bad habit anyway, but that's the con of the controls on these earbuds, from my POV anyway.5. Overall quality - I really can't complain about these earbuds. I've dropped them in the sink while washing my face, and forgotten to take them out when taking a shower (I realized after the water hit my head that I was still listening to whatever it was I was listening to, but they got a good dose of water sprayed on them, and there were times where one did fall out of my ear, primarily because I didn't seat it well.I have been so pleased with these earbuds, that I bought my 17 yr old son a pair and he is also very happy with them. He listens to music primarily, 70-80-90's music (yeah he has good taste in music for a teenager.) :-)An update after I had written this. I ran into a problem with the left earbud not connecting to BT. I contacted Sony support because they have a 1 yr limited warranty, and I bought these back in May of last year. We tried doing a full reset, which didn't correct the problem. The CSR provided me the info to send them back, I received an email with a FedEx shipping label, dropped them off at the Fedex in a Dollar General nearby, 2 days later they arrived at the Sony repair facility, 1 day after that, Sony notified they had ordered a brand new pair of WF-C500's for me and I should get them next week.I'm not usually the kind of guy that gets massively butt-hurt when something breaks. Stuff happens. What I don't enjoy is when I am trying to correct a problem, be it a defect or whatever, with the manufacturer or the store and it becomes a battle of will and plain old integrity of service. My experience with Sony was outstanding. They asked me to try and correct the issue by doing a hard reset and when that didn't work, they moved right into replacement mode. I dig and respect that. So I wholeheartedly recommend this product. Unlike the growing number of Shamazonians who get free stuff to test and write reviews even though in all honestly sometimes they don't know crap about the product, I am a guy who buys his own stuff and in this case, I was 110% daily user of these Sony WF-C500 earbuds - at home, in my truck, at the gym, in the kitchen, in the bathroom (oops), outside mowing my grass and running my airplane sounding weedeater, in all cases this audio was good, and most importantly, I didn't lose one out of my ear and run my mower over it. As far as "noise cancellation", I will just refer to the numerous times my bride yelled at me because I didn't hear her when she was talking to me. I suppose in some regards that counts as "noise cancellation". (my beautiful Brazilian bride, if you happen to read this, you know your man loves ya.)BLUF (Bottom Line Up Front): They feel good in the ear. They sound good in the ear. You don't look like you have a Chernobyl growth sticking out of your ears like some of the other earbuds. Perhaps best of all - Sony sticks behind their products and they understand what excellent customer service should be. These are the factors that drive my review and are the reason I bought a pair for my son, to whom I don't give him a rock when he asks for bread if you know what I mean. But he never asked for these, I knew the pair he had for 3+ years was having issues and wanted to surprise him. He was surprised on top of being happy. That's probably the highest recommendation I can provide, for what I give to the absolute pride and joy of my life - well I can't see these not being good enough for the King of England if they're good enough for my son.I'll TRY to remember and update my review with some pics when I get the new earbuds. Chances are however, that I will forget and probably remember when I'm in a situation that precludes me from executing the review update in that moment I'm thinking about it. But I'll try. BTW the price dropped on these. I paid $90 bucks for my pair and my sons pair, and I think I saw them for $70ish or $79 and they are worth every buck of that even at $90.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 23, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These are the best I have tried!
author: John
content: I don't write many reviews but after recently trying many different earbuds, I hope I can help others in their search. First off, I have spent over 20 years in the audio industry and consider myself myself somewhat of an audiophile - so sound quality is very important. Unfortunately, that time in the audio industry listening at high DBs has no doubt cost me some hearing - so strong volume is also very important to me.Thanks to Amazon's return policy I have tried many highly rated ear buds under $100 on the market:Ear Fun Free Pro 2 = Great sound, great NC, good volume but would NOT stay in my ears,Soundcore Anker Life P3 = great sound quality, features, but NOT loud enough.SoundPeats MiniPro AC = Great volume, good sound but stick out way too far and fall out of my ears.Palm Buds Pro = just not loud enough!Soundcore Life A2 NC+ = Great Sound, Great volume, great features but stick out too far and also fall out of my ers!Now on to these Sony WF-C500s = Great sound, very good volume, 10 hour battery life, well designed case, nice app, and fit my ears like a glove. Heck I can even side sleep and not usually press a control accidentally, I have had no problems with people hearing me on phone calls. I can work out and they don't fall out of my ears! While they are not overly bass heavy (more true to the music), it can't be beefed up with the EQ in the app. I made a Custom EQ with pretty much the same settings as the Treble Boost EQ but raised the Clear Bass setting. The result is more than adequate bass, good separation and very good volume. I ordered all the above buds about the same time and when I tried these Sony's I figured they were the keeper. After trying all the others I mentioned, I kept coming back to these WF-C500s! Did I mention these fit like they were actually designed to go in a person's ears?
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 5, 2022

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars First impression - You get what you pay for
author: Jake
content: Had these for a day now. They're alright.They stay in my ears surprisingly well, the battery lasts much longer than I'll ever need it to. The case is made of a pretty cheap feeling plastic, but the buds themselves feel higher quality.My main issue with these is that the audio quality (by default, at least) is HORRIBLE. Maybe I'm just spoiled by higher quality, wired earbuds but they are far below average by most standards. The saving grace, however, is that the app lets you tamper with the different levels and tune the audio to your liking. I managed to get it to sound a bit better, but I couldn't find a way to make the audio any louder which is unfortunate. The buds are very quiet.Overall they're pretty good. If you're able to spend more, it may be worth it, but they're great value for the price.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars My first wireless earbuds (good for on the go but that's it)
author: Scott D. Briggs
content: I've only had them for a day or two so haven't used them extensively yet, but, I can see whatthe usual Bluetooth shortcomings are. The comfort level isn't great although it depends on earsand type and size of the tips, ok, they fit snug, they charge easily and last a long time on charge,very convenient for running around town, etc. walks, exercise, shopping, etc. However, with myiPhone or lossless player, I never, ever achieve the type of power and volume and quality levelsthat I get with my full wired headphone amp/player Fiio rig. These get somewhat loud butnot very, they seem to be limited to a certain threshold and it doesn't matter what the sourceis. I never have those issues with my full wired headphone and IEM rig.For serious listeningI would opt for the latter, always, but the Sony C500 are good when I just want to run aroundtown and even drive and cannot use the full rig I have. The comfort level wasn't great,though, which is a reason I often don't love IEMs or earbuds. For the money these soundpretty good, clear, but I cannot get the type of audiophile performance from them I wouldhope for, due to the wireless, so I guess I just don't love wireless so far. Meanwhile I owna brand new 70 watts per channel BT speaker that blows these earbuds out of the waterin every respect. But that's a fully amped full range portable speaker.Until Sony and other mfgrs. come up with a fully built-in self-amplified BT IEM or earbud,these will be for convenience only, really. They are cool but don't make me want to sitwith them in my ears (uncomfortably) for hours on end. For the $45 that I paid for themthough, I guess they're a good value for on the go usage. They were easy to pair and easyto figure out how to use them for controlling them, and the Sony apps. I downloaded to usewith them seem to work just fine, but what's the use of EQ and all that when the deviceitself is limited totally in terms of amp power and volume? And the power coming outof the iPhone is limited?

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Okay, but a couple design flaws
author: shang
content: I've been a part time audio engineer for decades, so I have a pretty good ear. Overall they sound pretty good for under $50. The 2 issues I encountered are:1) They don't get loud enough. I used them while I was mowing my lawn and the noise cancelling gets rid of some of the background noise, but not enough to immerse a person in their music if there's something loud in the background.2) They don't go deep enough into the ear canal. In ear monitors need to couple with your ear canal in order to stay in place and reproduce low frequencies well. This made them very light in the bass and if I tried to boost the bass with my phone's EQ, it would start to distort at "high" volumes.If they went about a 1/4" deeper it might take care of both problems. I'll probably look for different ear pieces to attach to these that will go deeper into the ear canal.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Solid product for the price, but not hifi.
author: hi viz backpack
content: These earbuds are great! They pair with my phone quickly and reliably. Battery life is certainly all I need. They work great for phone calls / Zoom. Plastic is solid, etc. Panasonic engineers really did a good job with all these important "liveability" considerations.Where these earbuds fall short is sound quality. I'd say fidelity from these is in the ballpark of television sound. For news, podcasts, audiobooks, social media, they're smooth and spoken content is perfectly intelligible. But you won't see YoYo Ma listening to music with them. I mean, c'mon, they cost $25-$30. If you want high fidelity, open your wallet.When listening to music, I have other very good options for hifi playback. These little Panasonics are for carrying in my pocket day to day, and if one gets lost, it's not the end of the world thanks to their low price.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very nice
author: Bridgette
content: Being a huge fan of the Panasonic ergofit wired buds, these were a prime choice for my first pair of Bluetooth earbuds ever. Suffice to say I love Bluetooth earbuds now and will never go back to wired. These buds are great. The charge lasts forever. With a good custom EQ, and Dolby Atmos ON, they provide very nice bass and clear voices. The sound quality is on par with the wired version, all things being equal, as these do have the extra bass from their larger drivers.The buds are black, clean, and no fuss with a neat little angle in them for the "ergo-fit" gimmick. I don't think they fit any better than other earbuds, but they do look nice. The buds are also quite large with their 10mm drivers, almost seeming oversized. This gives them a more expensive look.Unlike my husband's other brand of wireless buds, these buds have NO LEDs on the buds themselves, which I quite enjoy. No annoying red/blue lights blinking constantly, and also saves battery, I imagine.Pairing was very simple and quick on my S20 Ultra, without reading any instructions whatsoever, and just opening the case, they immediately showed in the Bluetooth connection and paired quickly. They seem to pair far faster and more reliably than my husband's wireless buds. Simply turn bluetooth on, and tap "RZ-B310W". My husband's initial set up for his buds was an annoying dance of pairing each bud separately, and opening and closing the case. These buds both pair at same time, every time for me, and can connect even when they're inside the case charging.The case is nice, minimalistic and has a nice magnetic snap close. No LED screen like my husband's earbuds, but I find that an unnecessary expense. There's a little red LED light to show when it's charging. The tiny case holds many hours of charge, and I'm surprised daily that the buds just keep going, even though I'm wearing them a good portion of the day.The buds snap magnetically into their ports, and I will admit it can be a pain when you go to put them back in figuring out which one goes in which port, as they only go in one way.The buds fit in my ears is "OK", not perfect. I have small ear canals. They do stay in, but I can tell when the seal gets broken if I smile or laugh and they move out of place the tiniest bit.That's a small annoyance rather niche for people with tiny ear canals like myself though.I never read the instructions so figured out by trial and error how to activate the different modes and things like pause. Currently to change mode, I cup my palm against the bud as if to push it further in my ear for a couple seconds until I hear the voice over saying what's been activated. Still haven't figured out exactly where to touch and hold with one finger to change modes, but my way works for me.To pause/play, I press a fingertip against the round back of the bud. Unfortunately it's probably quicker to just use your phone to pause/play, as you cannot just tap the bud but have to press and hold for a second. On the other hand, that's a positive as it's much harder to accidentally hit it, unlike my husband's buds, where he often hangs up mid-call because he pushed the bud for a split second to get it back in his ear fully.So, about the noise cancellation, it's pretty nice! There's definitely a noticeable difference between the three modes. I didn't buy these for noise cancelling, but wanted to try it out as I've never had noise cancelling buds.There's "Ambient Sound", which amplifies your surrounding noise to hear comfortably even while wearing earbuds. Makes hearing others, and safety sounds like traffic, loud and clear. Not ideal to use when just chilling at home, as it makes surrounding noise very loud, but great in public or if walking/jogging/biking on a road or having a conversation with someone else.There's the option "Off" which seems to be just the default experience of wearing normal earbuds. Sound is slightly muffled, but still comes through.Finally, the option for "Noise Cancelling", which is quite striking when you use it for the first time. In my room with an AC on and white noise in the background, it dramatically lowered the apparent noise coming into my ears to a near imperceptible whisper. If I didn't know better, I would've thought there was NO AC or white noise in my room and it was near-silent.So, the noise cancellation works great for continuous sounds, yes. But other dynamic noises like human voices, it doesn't work as well. If you are buying these for the noise cancelling element, like if you, say, live in a noisy house and want to sleep better at night, I'd choose a more robust set with great active noise cancelling. Or if you just want to drown out ALL noise around you. But I will say, with noise cancelling on, and some brown noise playing on the buds from YouTube, that would provide a good night's sleep in a noisy home for sure, and it's been done many times by myself since getting these buds.... Only issue is finding them in the morning as they inevitably fall out with my tossing and turning!But I didn't buy these for noise cancelling, though it was a gimmick I wanted to try. I bought these for sound quality, and they deliver, when set up correctly. I've never been one to just use the default sound settings on my phone/PC for any pair of buds I've had, but my initial impression from the DEFAULT EQ on my S20 Ultra was that, out of the box, the buds were too bass-forward for me, at the loss of necessary mids and highs. They sounded a bit, muffled. In music, I prefer the voice to be at the forefront and crystal clear in the genres I enjoy. I also listen to a lot of podcasts, so I quickly did a custom EQ to suit my needs, and I recommend everyone does for *any* pair of headphones they have, as it can make a huge difference. I do listen to rap and hip-hop occasionally, but if that is your *predominant* preference, these may be perfect for you out of the box without adjustment. For other genres and general listening, in my opinion, these are too bassy. I want the bass to be there, but not as front as it comes in these earbuds.There's a nifty setting on the newer android phones to make a custom EQ right in the sound settings without a separate app, and even a way to get a personalized EQ by testing your hearing, to adjust for the loss of perception that comes with age. I recommend playing around with that and making your own custom equalizer to suit your needs if you don't like the initial sound quality.It's exceedingly rare I get a pair of headphones that sound to my liking out of the box, as these days heavy bass is so championed.All that being said, I'm very satisfied with my first set of wireless buds, and I think Panasonic knocked it out of the park at this price point, just like they did with the ergo-fit wired buds I've loved for years.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars For the price they are pretty good, but not a great fit for my son

content: The sound is pretty good for earbuds in this range, I think. But they can be a little hard to get to stay in your ear. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 8, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Quite impressive
author: Yan L.
content: The Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds with Noise Cancelling have impressed me with their exceptional sound quality and convenient features. From their sleek design to their powerful audio performance, these earbuds provide a satisfying listening experience that will elevate your music enjoyment.The first thing that caught my attention was the ergonomic design of the earbuds. They fit snugly and comfortably in my ears, thanks to the multiple sizes of ear tips included in the package. The lightweight construction ensures extended periods of use without discomfort, making them suitable for daily activities or intense workout sessions.The sound quality delivered by these earbuds is truly remarkable. The built-in noise cancelling technology effectively blocks out ambient noise, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in your favorite tunes. The audio is crisp, clear, and well-balanced, with a particular emphasis on the powerful bass response. The XBS (Extra Bass System) feature adds depth and richness to the low-end frequencies, enhancing the overall listening experience, especially for bass enthusiasts.With Bluetooth 5.3 connectivity, pairing the earbuds with my device was seamless and hassle-free. The wireless connection remained stable even when moving around, and I experienced minimal latency while watching videos or playing games. The touch controls on the earbuds provide easy access to playback controls, volume adjustment, and even voice assistant activation, making it convenient to manage your audio on the go.The included charging case is compact and sleek, serving as a secure storage solution for the earbuds while also providing additional battery life. The case's built-in battery can recharge the earbuds multiple times, ensuring that you can enjoy your music throughout the day without worrying about running out of power. The USB-C charging port offers fast charging capabilities, minimizing the downtime between listening sessions.While the Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds deliver excellent sound quality and convenient features, there are a few areas where they could be further improved. The battery life of the earbuds themselves could be extended, as they offer around 4-5 hours of continuous playback, which may not be sufficient for long trips or extended listening sessions without access to the charging case. Additionally, the touch controls on the earbuds can sometimes be overly sensitive, leading to accidental commands.Overall, the Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds with Noise Cancelling offer an impressive audio experience, combining powerful bass, effective noise cancelling, and convenient features in a compact design. Whether you're a music lover, a fitness enthusiast, or someone who appreciates wireless freedom, these earbuds deliver on their promise of immersive sound and provide great value for their price.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 13, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars A good performer
author: WT
content: The Panasonic RZ-B310W is not currently compatible with the Panasonic Audio Connect app so you are limited to the controls available on the earbuds and there isn't an equalizer. Controls available using the touch panels on the earbuds include music control (pause, forward, backward) and sound control (ANC, ambient sound, off). Unfortunately, sound control toggles from ANC to Off to Ambient Sound. This means it takes two touches to go from ANC to Ambient Sound and I find that to be a bit annoying. I prefer going from ANC to Ambient to Off. You can also turn the buds on or off using the touch panels. The earbuds are lightweight, comfortable and fit my ears well. I can get a good seal using the included eartips and the sound isolation is very good. Construction quality is excellent as you would expect from Panasonic. The charging case is small and will easily slip into a pocket.The earbuds are tuned too bright for my liking. I use the equalizer in my music app to tune the earbuds. The bass is strong without being boomy but sounds a bit loose. The overall sound signature is V-shaped but pleasing to the ear. However, you must get a good seal or the sound is really messed up, with little bass, no midrange and shrill highs. These earbuds are not for critical listening but if you want something for casual listening while commuting or working at your desk, give these a try.Noise isolation and bass response depends on your achieving a good fit with one of the included eartips. If you can't get a good seal, the bass will be nearly non-existant and the treble will overpower everything.Active noise cancellation is better than I expected. It isn't at the level of the Sony WF-1000XM4 or Bose QuietComfort Earbuds 2 but it does reduce a significant amount of low frequency noise, like the roar of jet engines. To be honest I wasn't expecting this level of noise cancellation in a $99 earbud. It also does a fair job of reducing office noises.I don't normally use earbuds to make to take calls so I haven't checked the voice quality during calls.Overall, I'm very pleased with the RZ-B310W. I can easily recommend them as one of the best I've used under $100. A good value.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 9, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Fine for the Price - But I Have Quirks
author: Romain
content: Overall, I think these earbuds are good for the price point, but it has a few quirks that make using them less enjoyable.Sound Quality is its best feature. I tested them against my son's AirPods Gen 2 and my AirPod Pros Gen 1 on an iPhone via Apple Music. My go to song to test listening devices is Ray Charles "Georgia on my Mind" (mid volume). That song has a lot happening, and I can pick-up how well the device is as letting you hear all the details. I thought the Panasonic sounded better than the AirPod, and it held its own against the AirPod Pro. Had I played other songs, I think the Pro would win outright because of Spatial Audio features. For added fun, I listen to the track with a wired Beats earbud (lighting cord), and that beat all 3 of them.Ergonomics is Terrible. As others have mentioned, just to get it out of the case is a challenge, if you have larger fingers. When you take it out of your ears, it still plays. That is not necessarily a bad thing, but worth nothing. The case is nice looking but it does not have a sturdy feel. I case see it cracking with a moderate fall to the ground.Software and Other Quirks makes it hard to love. To start, there was no feedback on the case to tell you when it was fully charged, charging the case or charging the ear buds. Same goes with low battery. I could not make out when I needed to charge it, other than waiting for it to not play or connect. Perhaps the app is suppose to help with that? With a good app, it probably would be manageable.It's a very possessive device. As mentioned, I have multiple buds. If I start using the Panasonics, and decide to switch to another device, the Panasonics kept trying to jump back in, even when the buds were in the case. I don't know if I got a bad one or what, but a few times I had to move it away from my phone to get it to not try to take over.If it will be your only bluetooth listening device, and you don't plan on using the buttons, I think it would be fine. For me, I am already slotting the Panasonics as my TV at night device or another dedicated source to avoid it getting confused.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 17, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Touch controls are difficult to use and don't work with Android phone
author: Olivia
content: These headphones have some positives, but in general I don't think they are worth the money. You can get better earbuds for cheaper than this.To start with, the things I like about them: the fit. I like that they are angled into my ears, and stay in very securely. They come with different headphone tips, although the default ones were just fine for me. I've used these while running and don't slip around or start to fall out.I think the sound is decent -- not great, but not terrible. The bass is well balanced. I also use these for video calls and people report they can hear me well. In video calls, other people's voices sound slightly harsh, which I don't love. But they are definitely servicable sound. If you're really into audio balancing, you probably won't like these, though.The noise cancelling is also somewhat mediocre. I can kinda tell it's doing something, but when people are talking nearby or my dogs bark elsewhere in my house, I can hear it. They don't have the kind of noise cancelling where you put on and remove your headphones and can really notice the difference the noise cancelling makes.The thing I like the least about these are the touch controls. They are really tough to get to work and they don't work beyond play/pause with my Android phone (Pixel 7 pro). When I use these paired to my computer, I have to really focus on how I tap and where exactly my finger lands to get the controls to respond. If I'm wearing these out while running, I have to stop running and hold still to get the play/pause to work. Otherwise, if I'm paired with my phone, I can't get it to advance/repeat track or change volume. I tried downloading the Panasonic devices app, thinking that might be the issue, but I can't get that to work at all (it never pairs with the headphones and is stuck in a loop).In the end, these aren't worth the money to me. I'd rather spend more for a more solid product that works, like Airpods or GalaxyBuds, or go for a cheaper pair that might not have the nice fit, but has more functional touch controls.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 4, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Punchy sound and a comfortable fit
author: expatbrit
content: These are impressive earbuds that do a lot of things right and only come up short in 2 areas.The sound is bass heavy, as expected from the XBS feature, and it can produce some really meaty lows, but this can be dialed down with a good equalizer.Out of the box they sounded a little underwhelming but they improved steadily after a dozen hours or so. I still prefer the more enveloping sound of my Soundpeats buds, but these are more than acceptable, especially with a high bit rate streaming service.There's plenty of volume on tap and the Bluetooth range is a little more than 30 feet, about par for the course across similar products.Panasonic is always good at proving clear instructions, but only the quick start guide is useful here, with picture based instructions. The little booklet offers safety advice in multiple languages, an odd inclusion.One thing these RZs excel at is comfort. Once you find the right rubber tips (3 sizes included) then they stay put, some of the best I've tried. Even talking and eating couldn't shift them, a rare find in my experience. These would make excellent buds for the gym.Battery life is a key selling point on the box, and it's proving correct so far; with minimal charging and extended use, no 'battery low' warning yet. Charging is via a USB C type port, widely becoming the standard these days.One downside is the fiddly shape of the bud and the case, it's all too smooth with no real area to grip, so getting them out of the case takes practice. The touch controls are also slow to respond but work well enough once you get the right zone at the top of the stalk.There's no noise cancelling to speak of (I have tested them on a plane) but they don't claim to have it, so that's OK.For the user looking for a good all-round set of wireless buds, from a household name that will almost certainly be around to honor a warranty in years to come, these are a solid value.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars An affordable option that deliver good results on sound quality and functionality
author: Kevin
content: Although I am not a power-user when it comes to wireless earbuds, I am picky when it comes to comfort, and most importantly, sound quality. For may years now I have used AirPods and AirPods Pro models. I have generally been very satisfied with them, with the latter being a little less comfortable for me than I would prefer, and sound quality of both being on the above average side. And as far as functionality, they have worked pretty much flawlessly for me.When I saw these Panasonic ErgoFit earbuds, they seemed to boast the features that I tend to look for ‚Äì good sound, Bluetooth connectivity, noise cancelling, a portable charging case ‚Äì and of course, good sound quality with good base.My overall impression of the Panasonic‚Äôs is on the good side of the spectrum. As far as sound quality, in my opinion, I have found them to be on par with my AirPod Pros, and better than my standard AirPods, but that should be expected given that the Panasonics seal in your ears just like the AirPod Pros do. I‚Äôve also found the noise cancelling and ambient sound modes to work very well. I would however give the edge to the Pros on ambient sound mode. The Panasonics have something of a white-noise in the background when using ambient sound mode, and it is noticeable when you are not playing music.On phone calls, I can hear very clearly, and based on my testing, callers can also hear me very clearly, so the microphones do a very good job on phone calls. I would say that they seem to pick up a little more ambient noise than my AirPods, and callers can hear more background noise when speaking to me. But overall, unless you are doing something noisy, they work fine.As far as fitment goes, I‚Äôve found these to be bulkier than my Airpods and AirPod Pros. I would also say they are just slightly less comfortable than the Pros as well. But, given the activities that I use ‚Äúear-sealing‚Äù earbuds for, like jogging, mowing the lawn and working outside, I find them to be more than comfortable enough. Comfort is very subjective, so these may or may not be a good option for you.As to overall build quality, the Panasonic earbuds themselves feel solid and well made. The case on the other hand has something of an empty feeling to it, unlike the Apple cases which feel sturdy and well made. But regardless, the case works just fine, which ultimately is what matters.I have noticed that the Bluetooth connection with the Panasonics is not as resilient as it is with either pair my AirPods. In an open and unobstructed environment, the reliability of the connection, and the range of the connection is perfectly fine. However, if you introduce obstructions and if you change the orientation of your body, you will start losing the connection. If you keep your phone on your person this should not be a problem, but I like to place my phone down somewhere safe while I am mowing or if I am working on projects outdoors, and I have been annoyed by the tendency of the connection to drop more often than the AirPods do.So overall, what do I think about the Panasonic ErgoFit earbuds? Well, I like that you can get good sound quality while listening or speaking - and out of earbuds for under $100 dollars as not everyone has the money to purchase more expensive options. While the Panasonics lack some of the refinement of more expensive units, they put out good sound and offer the convenience of a portable charging case like their more expensive cousins. For working out, working outdoors, or just working around the house while jamming some tunes, I see these as an affordable option that shouldn't disappoint you, particularly as these are a value item in my opinion. I do feel like they could do a little bit better on the price though - $80 seems like an attractive figure, and the lower the cost gets under that $100 price point, the more attractive these Panasonics become.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Pretty great headphones.
author: Elizabeth Mays
content: I unintentionally tested these out under some of the best conditions possible: a room full of teachers at their professional development at the beginning of a school year. The sound was amazing, and I was able to focus on what I was doing and what I was listening to instead of all the chaos around me... but the sound from all the other teachers talking and joking around me was not completely canceled. It was more like hearing them from underwater: I was aware of the sound, the tempo or cadence of people speaking, but couldn't make out what they were saying and a couple of times I had to figure out that someone was talking to me because they were trying to make eye contact. I could hear them speaking, but could not make out the words.They are very comfortable, and they last for a long time, and I think they are a good level of noise limiting, but not quite canceling.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars I would order these again!

content: I ordered these for myself because my old earbuds stopped charging. These are a little bit too big for my ears but I have small ear canals. I would say for most folks these are going to be a nice¬†and snug fit. They are comfortable and I don't even notice they are in my ears. I must say the sound quality is very good to excellent and the noise canceling really does block out noises in your immediate environment. These are the most expensive¬†earbuds¬†I have owned so far and I am not an expert at listening to music with earbuds. They were easy to connect with my Android Note 9 phone. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2023

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Disappointing
author: Rob M.
content: I have owned and tested dozens of true wireless earbuds over the past few years.I really wanted to like these earbuds, but they have too many flaws. There are better choices out there at this or lower price points.Pros- Small, pocketable case- Good build quality. Solid Panasonic reputation.- Very comfortable "Ergofit"- Minimal in-ear adjustment required after insertion. They stay in place pretty well for non-winged earbuds, but do require infrequent adjustments in my wonky ears.- Sound quality is very good, even without EQing. Balanced. Good "XBS" bass, good treble. Compared to Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro, they rate 8/10 on sound.Cons- No wireless charging- A little awkward to get in and out of the case- No app support, which means no firmware updates to potentially improve them over time.- No app means no control customization.- No app means no EQ unless you use a 3rd-part EQ app like Wavelet, XEQ, or your music player's built-in EQ.- Cannot control volume from the earbuds, aside from summoning the digital assistant and asking it to turn the volume down. Cumbersome. Faster to just do it on your phone.- Controls are just OK. Sometimes you have to tap more than once to get them to register. And they seemed to respond more when I tapped below the visible sensor area than on it, but that's probably something I could adjust to in time.- ANC - The noise cancelling is just OK. It does work, and there is a marked difference between Off, Transparent Mode, and Noise Cancelling Mode. But it is not nearly as good as the Pixel Buds Pro, Liberty 3 Pro, or Earfun Free Pro 2.- Bluetooth connection stability. They have Bluetooth 5.3, as does my Pixel 7 phone. Despite un-pairing and re-pairing several times with my phone, they would frequently lose pairing, then re-pair. Sometimes they would not re-pair or re-connect without putting them back in the case and pulling them back out. During playback, they would have several very short interruptions or glitches per song. Very quick, like a record skipping, but still quite noticeable and aggravating. Sometimes when grasping the stem to adjust their fit in my ear, they lose connection and say "pairing". If buds can't stay connected, they are useless. I don't have these problems with other buds.- As is true with most buds, if they lose seal the sound quality degrades a lot. No bass, shrill treble, and no ANC because of outside sound leakage. You have to adjust them to get the seal and the bass back. But there's a 50/50 chance they'll lose connection when you grasp the stem to adjust.- Phone voice quality is just OK. The clarity is fine, but the volume is quiet. Callers have a hard time hearing me unless I speak quite loudly.I don't feel these buds are worth $100. They have a solid Panasonic brand name & build quality, but they offer too little for the money. A $50-65 price point is more realistic for these buds.Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro list for $169 but are frequently discounted to $129 or even $99.Earfun Free Pro 2 or Air Pro 3 are less than $99.Pixel Buds Pro list for $199 but are often on sale for $149.I would choose any of those over these Panasonics.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lots of bass, ANC, ambient mode, not the most comfortable.
author: Avid83
content: These Panasonic earbuds are awesome for listening to music with deep bass. They connect easily to your iPhone or PC via Bluetooth and have a stable connection. They come with different sizes of rubber tips, but they could fit better in your ears. Maybe longer stems would help. Fortunately, these are lightweight, but not the most compact design.The earbuds have some cool features like noise cancelling, ambient mode, and a low latency mode called ‚Äúgame mode.‚Äù You can turn on game mode by tapping the earbuds 5 times quickly. It makes games and videos in sync, but sometimes it‚Äôs prone to dropouts. Active noise cancelling works well at reducing outside sounds, but also introduces some low but noticeable noise. I didn‚Äôt try exercising with these, but they do have an IPX4 water resistant rating.The touch sensors on these earbuds are not very responsive and have a delay. You have to get used to them and find the right spot to tap. You can't control the volume with them, but you can do other things like skip tracks, pause, answer calls, and use voice assistants. The earbuds don't fall out of your ears, but they do slip a bit over time and have to be readjusted. Battery life seems good, and the charging case uses a USB-C connection, although the included cable fits unusually tight.Although not perfect, these earbuds have a lot of modern features like ANC and a USB-C connection to charge the case. I would recommend them, but the fit may not be the best depending on the shape of your ears.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars These are ok, the range isn't great

content: For these earbuds to be on the higher end for price, they're not that impressive. They do have good sound, I'll give them that. The battery like is average at about 6 hours. title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Low on volume, awkward controls, but alright earbuds.
author: opal
content: I have a different set of earbuds that I'm pretty happy with, but they keep falling out of my ears and the shape gets uncomfortable after an hour or so of use, so I wanted to try this style out. Since Panasonic is a brand I grew up around, I had high hopes for these earbuds.These paired easily with my phone, and they're comfortable on my ears for their whole two and a half hour battery life.These earbuds are a pain to get out of the case, even with my small hands and somewhat long nails.The controls are AWFUL. They're difficult to master, rarely react the same way twice except to pause when I'm trying to skip, I cannot skip songs nor activate the ANC, and there's very little about the controls in the instruction booklet aside from a leaflet with mostly pictures- the other booklet is a European warranty that lacks a language that I can understand. I have no clue what the picture means for how to activate the ANC, so I gave up on that front. I can just barely get these to answer calls, so I don't bother. I use my phone's controls over the ones on these earbuds, they're so difficult to work with.I have to turn off my phone's bluetooth to disengage these earbuds from it.The volume on these is not stellar- at their max, I'm just barely satisfied with the volume, even when using VLC. Sometimes I want louder music to drown out construction work and the industrial-level banging at the nearby oil well- these cannot do that.However I do find that the sound is overall reasonably balanced, and the strength of the bass is adequate- but not great. The highs and mids are so-so: nothing to complain about, but the mids get muddy in certain ranges, and the highs are a tad too sharp at certain tones. I think that these are fine for casual use, but could be lacking for audiophiles.I can definitely say that I've used worse, but there's better earbuds out there.For a pair of earbuds from a such a well-known brand, these miss the mark. However for a pair of earbuds that let me listen to background music comfortably, these do the job fairly.Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds, Bluetooth 5.3 in Ear Headphones with XBS Powerful Bass, Charging Case ‚Äì RZ-B110W
