title: 4.0 out of 5 stars As buying or upgrading from wf4, what you should know
author: Amazon Customer
content: First I do need the ANC, because I am using a laptop, when gaming, the fan noise is very huge, so ANC is a key feature to me.And my conclusion is wf4 and wf5 has the same amount ANC as I can feel, the fan noise I can hear through the ear buds are the sameNest thing, the tips, sony changed the materials this time, the out side of the ear tips wont stick on you canal this time, it comes off much easier than the previous generation, surprisingly even I don‚Äôt feel like my ear canal is full sealed like wf4, but the amount of ANC I am receiving is the sameThird matter, you have the option of TRUN OFF the sidetone on the wf5I personally did contacted sony, of wishing they can make this as a future of letting users to turn on or off the sidetone, in which when you use mic, the sound comes from the ear buds will stay the same, and if you consider to buy them for gaming, it really is a point to upgrade for.4, the control on the ear buds changed, like wf4 where you can only get 1 set of unchangeable command on each of the earbuds, wf5 has the same thing, but the volume adjustment is changed, unlike last gen you have to set a earbud of the function, now it is hitting left side 4 times repeatedly for lower the volume and right side of increase the volume. Very annoying to be honest, compare to the last gen I changed left side as volume control, in which I can hold and adjust the volume, but this one you have to keep hitting it.About the comfort, they about the same, I can not tell the difference between each other.Overall if you buying this for gaming, or you are a customer representative at work need microphone a lot, it is kind worth buy it or upgrade from WF4, simply because you can turn off the sidetone on wf5.Besides that there aren‚Äôt noticeable or meaningful changes compare to the last gen.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 31, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Poor fit, I guess
author: Clams
content: I got these after reading good reviews and having connection problems with two different pairs of Bose QC ii earbuds. I had previously tried the xm4s, and they were good but too large for my ears and hurt after wearing them just 30-ish minutes. When I got these, I couldn't understand why the reviews had been so good. The ANC was just horrible. Definitely worse than the Bose and the XM4s. I've had them a couple of weeks and tried many different sets of ear tips and couldn't get any improvement. I mostly use earbuds at the gym, and with these, I could still clearly hear background noise and music, even over the sound of my own music. Sometimes the noise comes through so clearly that I can't believe the ANC is even turned on.Finally after two weeks using them, I tried pressing them further into my ears and holding them there. When I do that, the ANC is great, but they won't stay in that deeply unless I hold them, so I'll need to return them. Apparently these are just not a good fit for my ears and I can't get a decent seal.Other:*The multi-point connection is great and works really well. It's ridiculous that the Bose doesn't have that.*Battery life is as advertised.*These are much smaller and more comfortable than the XM4s. The case size in a lot smaller and convenient.*Having to tap four times to adjust the volume is stupid and annoying.*No "find my device" feature. I got a case and attached a Tile. Another ridiculous feature omission.*The earbud volume is not synced to the phone volume, at least not on my Pixel 7. This means that if I use the phone buttons to change volume, it will only change up or down to the point that the earbud volume is set at. If you want max volume, for example, you would have to max the volume on your phone and max it on the earbuds. The Bose were not like this. Adjusting the volume on the earbuds brings up the volume control on the phone.I decided to buy a used pair of the original Bose earbuds. I'd previously owned them and sold them when I got the Bose II. They are big and ugly, and the case is too big, but they worked properly without any of the issues or frustrations I've experienced with the Bose II and Sony XM4/XM5. (But I will say that I probably would have kept these xm5s if they had fit well enough for good noise cancellation.)

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars GREAT!! But...
author: Ryan Oswald
content: All the reviews about how awesome these are once you have them in your ears are absolutely correct: if anything better has been developed yet I don't know about it.Unfortunately, all that effort spent on the performance left functionality up the proverbial creek sans paddle.Just putting these in your ears will result in your music turning on and off a dozen or so times. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 9, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars *Early Impressions* A Marginal Upgrade To Their Already Great WF-1000XM4‚Äôs
author: April Villaaa
content: Coming from the previous model, the WF-1000XM4, these feel pretty familiar. Although the shape has been slimmed down, the fit is pretty similar but slightly less bulky and yet pretty comfortable.They come with more ear tips allowing a tight seal for a wider variety of ears (SS, S, M, L) medium being the standard that come preinstalled out of the box.The default sound signature has changed slightly, but thanks to the Sony Headphones Connect app, there‚Äôs an 5 band equalizer with presets and their iconic ‚ÄúClear Bass‚Äù slider for the bass heads. These earbuds can also produce more ‚Äúrich‚Äù low bass frequencies. Allowing for nice sub-bass that does not sound muddy and overpowering, but rather strong and detailed (depending on your EQ of course).Ambient sound happens to be weaker and sounds slightly less natural compared to the AirPods Pro 2, but good enough. Noise cancelling has been improved with slightly better performance with sudden noises like bangs and clanks, and even better/noticeable improvement with voices, hums and rumbles.(PS: Ambient sound still sucks when it‚Äôs windy due to excessive wind-flap noise. But, wind reduction during noise cancelling has been improved!)Lastly battery. Which appears to be about the same as the last model (about 8 hours on the earbuds, 24 hrs with the charging case), but the charging of the earbuds in the case is much faster! 60 minutes of playtime from 3-5 minutes of charging is not too crazy of a claim.Now, keep in mind that the WF-1000XM4 had problems with battery malfunction. And although Sony did usually replace the many faulty units of the previous model, this is something to watch out for as there is no way to tell if they‚Äôve improved it until a few more months have passed.Conclusion; If you‚Äôre currently an owner of the WF-1000XM4, I would wait for a bigger update. But if you‚Äôre upgrading from the WF-1000XM3 or even the AirPods Pro 2. This is a great product that will not leave you disappointed.Extra Features not tested:Multi-Device Connections, Head Gestures, Extensive Voice Call quality under difficult scenarios, In-device Voice Assistant.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 1, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Overrated
author: E7
content: I have the Sony WF-1000XM4 and now the XM5. The XM4 battery life is terrible. They have issues with those so don't get those. The XM5 noise cancellation is great and the music quality is good but I have a few complaints. The earbuds don't stay in my ear when using the original foam tips. It's annoying having your hands busy at work and feeling your earbud shifting about to fall out. I had to buy aftermarket foam tips. The sound could be better and it's probably due to the foam tips letting the sound out. My 2nd complaint is they're not loud enough. Even with aftermarket foam tips, the earbuds are just not loud enough. I work in a noisy environment and it's hard to listen to podcasts with these. The noise cancellation only works if you have both earbuds in. It sounds like it wants to work when using one earbud but only when there's a really loud noise. It cuts the music momentarily and goes back to letting all the noise in. It would really help if it would work with only one earbud in because I wouldn't have any problems hearing whatever I'm listening to. I hate the touch sensitive controls. I wish they had a physical button that gave me a clicky feedback every time I press it. There is a tone whenever you pause or skip but like I said, it's hard to hear in a noisy environment. Most of the time, I have to raise my volume to notice if it paused, skipped or didn't register me pressing the touch sensitive controls. I originally bought these to use while I'm at work but now I only use these at home. For work I use the Beats Studio Buds which are louder, stay in my ear (with comply foam tips), have great audio and have a clicky button for the controls. No more guessing if I pressed the button or not. With the Beats Studio Buds I can now listen to the same podcasts I couldn't hear with my XM5s in the same noisy environment. I just bought the Studio Buds + which have a better battery life than the 1st gen. The XM5s are overrated in my opinion.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 2, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great new size and fit....sound marginally better.
author: mallory623
content: I pre-ordered the WF-XM5s (black version) earlier this week and UPS delivered them this morning. I got them setup and connected to my iPad Pro, iMac, iPhone, Apple Watch and PC laptop. After using them for the better part of the day I personally don't feel any new great sound breakthrough or anything along those lines. The WF XM4's had a great balanced sound quality that I loved and they were my 'go-to' earphones for everything, over my Apple AirPods Pro, Kilpsch earphones, Bose Sound Comfort, Jabras and Master & Dynamics. This great balanced sound quality only continues in the WF XM5s. The overall sound staging is wonderful. Some people might prefer more bass though or more sparkly highs but for me the WF XM5s strike a perfect balance. Putting aside the marginal audio improvements, the big thing for me though was the new size. They're much smaller than the large bulbous WF XM4s and that was the big reason I was looking forward to these new ones. And I'm quite happy to report the size is definitely a welcome change. The WF XM4s would always start to wiggle loose in my ears after extended use and after a while, they almost get 'pushed' out of my ears unfortunately. Sony also added a new size to the ear tips, a 'SS' size (super small?). So it's L, M, S and....SS. The ear tips are made of new material and is supposed to enhance the sound quality. Meh, I don't hear much difference personally. The housing of the earphone is different too....more glossy not a matte finish like the WF XM4s. Not sure whether I like this or not but they do look different and I always like the color contrast of the gold Sony branding and gold mic with the black color housing. The ANC and call quality in my opinion still doesn't match some of my other earphones unfortunately. Still overall I'm quite happy with the new version, mainly because the sound quality hasn't diminished and they're much smaller. Looking forward to more software updates from Sony for the WF XM5s in the months to come...

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sound: A++ | Fit: B- | ANC: Depends
author: Kat
content: I concurrently tested these Sonys, Technics EAH-AZ80 and Sennheiser True Wireless 4. Thought the Sennheisers were going to win, as I was upgrading from the TW2s. Nope. The audio and customization capabilities on the WF-1000XM5s were unbelievable. It's like you're standing in a room with the band you're listening to, and you're able to pick out each instrument, each overdub, and every single layered vocal. And with the app, you can dial it in even further. Fantastic.CONS:The stock silicone tips are both uncomfortable and a poor fit. I bought some aftermarket foam tips, and they're more comfortable. But this was where the STW4s won out -- they were like pillows in your ears. Even with the new ones, they still come loose more often than I'd like.The case is fine, but not befitting of $300 buds. Sometimes great, sometimes meh.COLOR: I tried the black and the silver versions. Black ones and the case are classy and slick. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Disappointing until you get the right ear cups
author: Todd W.
content: I'm a big fan of the Sony line of noise cancelling headphones. I have the WF and WH series going back to 1003 versions. I purchased these on day 1 mainly because my 1004s got wet and the case no longer holds a charge. For the first two months I was extremely disappointed - sound and ANC was SIGNIFICANTLY worse than the previous version. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars A few questionable design decisions
author: George G
content: The ANC, sound quality and battery life are all excellent. The fit is an improvement over the M4s (which I returned due to battery and connection issues). But I'm taking a star for a few questionable design decisions.First, the buds are quite slippery and difficult to remove from the case. I can see this being a problem after exercise or during rainy weather. Some matte texture would have helped. What's weird is that they make this smoothness a selling point in the marketing material. How much did they test these in the real world?Second, and possibly worse long term, the eartips have a mesh to prevent debris from getting into the buds, but that's it. There is no foam inside the buds. If you need replacement eartips in the future, you'll want to find tips that have mesh protection, but after a cursory search on Amazon I don't see many options with a mesh. Now maybe you're like me and happy with the included tips, but In my experience they will wear out. So unless Sony starts selling their own replacements, this was a bad decision.In general, it feels like two steps forward on fundamentals, one or two steps back on design even if they are more comfortable.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good sound, hear through, noise cancelation, create routine profiles for work and home.
author: W Powell
content: They are good headphones nice sound and microphone. Loads of customizable setting. And the earbuds last about 4-5 hours continuous use and the case seems to support a single charge of the headphones not super impressed with the battery life
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 20, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sony > Bose
author: Zeke
content: I own both these Sony XM5 earbuds and the Bose Quietcomfort Ultra earbuds and i have to say that the Sony XM5 are the best all around. Sound quality is slightly better with Bose but unless youre a real stickler or dont know how to tweak the equalizer, it wont matter - theyre both professional audio companies and do what they do very well. really the only thing that i feel the XM5 buds lack is wingtips to help keep them in my ears. i have slept with the Bose buds and they stayed in my ears until i woke up. Sony buds are not best for small ears but even still, you will not regret choosing these over the Quietcomfort Ultra.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 4, 2024

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Sold my XM5s today. Just didn't like them
author: Michelle Welch
content: I really wanted to love them but in all honesty I just didn't. The Sony App is not great, the clarity was just ok and the bass was very lackluster.Had many issues connecting them to my gaming PC via Bluetooth that my PC would not even notice them at all.The ear tips are awful so had to be replaced and the touch controls were very sensitive. Just putting them in my ears I was turning things on and off.I have a pair of Tozo Golden X1 that blow these away in clarity and bass and the Tozo app is way more intuitive and touch controls are much nicer and I got my Tozo Golden X1 for 100 on Newegg and the Sonys cost 300.I will never buy expensive headphones again especially these. How is it the Sonys cost 3 times the price of the Tozo golden x1 and don't come close to what Tozo can do.No more
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 10, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Absolutely wonderful with one exception, and a note to some complaints
author: Nick J.
content: The sound is absolutely wonderful. I enjoyed my old buds. They had really good sound and great noise-cancelling. But what they didn't have, and what most infuriated me was how easily they came loose, which was a surprise due to the seemingly endless fitting options. These don't come loose when I work out, chew, walk, run, etc.I bought them when they went on sale for $50 off, and I see that they are priced even lower now ($26 less than the sale price).As to those who have complained that the magnets make them difficult to remove from the case, well, they need to read the instructions. You simply tilt each bud to the sides of the case, then lift them out. Simple.As much as I love these, they lost a star to one feature that is missing. The inability to program the button functions is frustrating. Four taps on the buds to adjust the volume? Yes, it's simple enough if you're sitting or standing still, but if you're walking, not even running, if you miss with a single tap, you can inadvertently activate another function.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Don't love them - they do the job
author: Nikki S.
content: The media could not be loaded. Did a ton of research on Bluetooth headphones and these came highly recommended for both usage, size, and budget. I personally am not a fan for a few reasons:1. Often times when I take the pods out of the case, only 1 headphones connects to my phone instead of both. I have to put the pods back in and take them out again for them to work. Easy fix, but super annoying.2. They will randomly disconnect and reconnect - so there will be random jumps or pauses in whatever I'm listening to.On the positives: the noise canceling is excellent, the battery life is great, headphones and case charge fairly quickly, and they are nice and small making it easy to slip into my pocket.Overall, I don't regret buying them -- but they're also not my favorite. Fall on the average scale for me.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Sony.
author: Runningbear91
content: The pros: First off the sound and the ANC is amazing!! I can barely hear my grinder when I'm the one using it. The sound quality is also one of the main reasons why i like this product. The equalizer, Dolby atmos and so on are very nice features.The cons: The fitment is great but I have weird shaped ears so many earbuds don't stay in my ears. The Bluetooth will intermittently cut out or lag out, and I have a Samsung S23 Ultra so I'm not sure why this does this. I had the older WF-1000Xm3 (best earbuds) so I had to have this pair which by the way, never cut out on sound or connection. The charging case also isn't quite up to par with its claims (bummer).Overall though, this pair of earbuds is awesome and although alittle older already, the price isn't too steep for what you get. A solid reputable sound quality banger with phenomenal ANC.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 27, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great Sound, Not as Loud as I Would Like
author: MA BOWDEN
content: I've been wanting some higher-end buds for a while and after waffling with a couple of other brands, I decided to try these Sonys. The sound quality is very good, especially when I get a tight seal in my ears, which is not always easy. The LDAC codec does make a subtle difference in sound quality for the better. (Higher quality sound available on some Android decices.) My only complaint is that I would sometimes like them to be a bit louder than they are. My main genre of music is classic rock, hence wanting the sound a bit louder. I used the app to tweak the equalizer more to my liking.The active noise reduction (ANR) works quite well. I haven't had buds with ANR before, so I do not really have anything to compare it to, but they do a good job of drowning out most ambient sounds when engaged. I have not used them for more than about 3 hours at a time yet, so I can't comment on battery longevity.Would I buy them again? Good question. I probably would if the price dropped some. If not, I would probably try another brand that cost about the same as these and also supports the LDAC codec.

author: I Demand Quality
content: I'm extremely picky with headphones I did sound and letting production for several years I notice subtle details. I would consider myself an sound, speaker, headphone enthusiast. My only complaint is that there's not a way to crank up the base to an overwhelming level as some people like me prefer to have excessive bass. But they do not have crappy base it's still there and when you have these earbuds you will listen to your favorite song you've listened to a million times and you're going to go I didn't hear that before or oh that sounds a little different I didn't hear that instrument like that type thing. Especially if you use ldac with lossless music even stuff from the 70s and 60s sounds remastered when it's og. Battery life is amazing. The only small thing that's weird about it is when I first got it I was like man these headphones suck cuz he can't take them out of the case easily but what you need to do is when you open your case just push the headphones to the side and they will come out easily. Last but not least if you're buying it renewed scroll through the list and try to find one that has the description of an original packaging and sold by Amazon warehouse because that's what I did I paid $100 less than what they're going for retail and mine were never ever opened I'm pretty sure it was but in returned without being opened.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good earbuds but airpod pro is better
author: Sports Fan
content: I found the earbuds awkward to handle, put in my ears, and remove them because i could not always get a good grip on them with my fingers and you have to rotate them in your ear and rotate them to get them out. I got use to it after a while but not as convenient as airpods.Connecting to my phone was easy and quick.The sound was very good. It is heavier on bass than airpods. The sound was rich and you could hear subtle details; however, some songs and some elements in the song like the singer‚Äôs voice or perhaps a guitar in the background did not standout as much as they should. I think it was due to the heavier bass.The controls of the right earbud did not work consistently (for play/pause and to increase the volume). This issue was particularly annoying and frustrating. Perhaps I got a dud right earbud?The noise cancelling is excellent and better than the airpod pro (which has good noise cancelling). I think the sony earbuds isolates sound better and may explain why the noise cancelling was noticeably betterOverall, these earbuds are good and if the airpod pro was not an option i think I would be happy with them provided that the control on the right earbud functioned consistently and reliably
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 24, 2023

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Noise cancelation minimal, wind noise too loud, voice activation & touch sensor too sensitive
author: D. Lewis
content: These buds were totally underwhelming.Noise Cancellation. The noise cancellation was negligible. Compared to my Apple earbuds (which didn't fit my ears well & broke after about 3 years due to planned obsolescence, I assume) that ran a sound test in my ear, these buds just didn't do much for ANC. I uploaded a 2nd app that it prompted me to get that took photos of my head and ears, but that app seemed to basically be trying to sell me more stuff. It did do some equalizer test, but I couldn't honestly hear much difference in most of the samples. The apple test was automated and I heard a huge difference once it was complete.Wind noise. I have these buds in my ears and the wind noise is incredible loud. This segues into the next point.Voice activation. It's too sensitive. Speak at all and whatever you're listening to stops. Wind noise even sometimes triggers this pause. This is annoying.Touch sensor. The touch sensor on the right bud is too sensitive. Reach up to adjust how the bud is seated in your ear and it pauses your track.I don't recommend.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 1, 2024

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars I hate these
author: Josh
content: I've had these for a few months now, daily use ever since.I think they're trash. I've used all sizes and all type of ear tips (standard, silicone, foam, hybrids) and the sound is never quite right, especially on non music things like podcasts and audiobooks... You can fiddle with the equalizer all you want and it will always sound just off enough to distract youThe ANC doesn't exist, you can hear everything the exact same with it on and off, I can have full conversations without any issues at all, it almost seems to do the exact opposite of what it shouldThe passthrough mode is the same way but opposite, if you set the ambient noise bar high enough it will make air conditioning sound like a jet engine but you can never understand what a person says, it sounds like they're telling through a tin can. It's easier to have a conversation with the noise cancelling ON!The battery life is fine, whatever, they charge quick and the left one dies faster than the right one.They slide out of my ears constantly, even with a great seal on foam tips I have to readjust a couple times an hourHuge regret purchase, wish I decided to do this review still within the refund window

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not Great
author: CTX
content: I'll try to make this as short of a story as possible. For a while, I've been seeking for the best/decent earbuds after my Pixel ones wore out. Multiple website reviews all directed me to these Sony WF-1000XM5. Thus, I purchased these earbuds and was greatly disappointed to some features/details that weren't mentioned on product pages or reviews:1) Degradable earbud tips - Yep, the ear pieces are super soft foam but biodegradable. I get the whole trying to limit waste in the environment, but if I'm spending $200+ on earbuds, I'd like for the material to last more than 6 months.2) Case felt like recycled hard foam - Same as above, for the price asked, it's just not right.3) Volume controls - This was the main thing that killed it for me. Gesture/Touch interface is terrible. To raise/lower volume, one must repeatedly tap the earbud four times, which only raises/lowers by one level. The app has options to change some gesture/touch but nothing for volume. It goes back to my previous nitpicks: If I'm spending way too much on headphones, I better be getting something near perfect.Sound on the earbuds were great, and the fit was the most comfortable I have felt in years. However, due to the three things mentioned above, the $250 pricetag was not worth it for me.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sounds amazing, good battery life, and ANC is almost perfect
author: John T. Layne
content: These are my first actual pair of nice ear buds and they do not disappoint. I spent some time researching and eventually landed on these as my choice. ANC is about 95% blocking out all other noise, the features are great in the app to configure them, and so far the battery life is stellar. However, the sound quality is the most impressive by far and large. I walk in the gym on treadmills and I can't hear a large fan blowing directly at my head nor could I hear people talking around me, but as far as the audio I can hear rich bass and highs so well that even in previously viewed youtube videos I was hearing things I couldn't before. I also use them while connected to my computer via bluetooth while flying in the sim in VR. These things are incredible!The only drawback I will say is that to adjust the volume you have to repeatedly tap on the left or right bud and sometimes if it doesn't register a tap you may end up having them do one of the quick functions. This isn't that big of a deal for me though as I adjust my volume from my phone or computer.Also, if one bud is out you lose the functions that bud provides. So if the left bud is out I cannot toggle ANC, and if the right bud is out I can't stop playback. Not a deal breaker for me though.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2024
